title: AGRICULTURE MARKET ATLAS OF MADHYA PRADESH
text:
About the Authors



Mr. Gourav Kumar Vani is serving as Assistant Professor (Agricultural Economics) in the Department of Agricultural Economics and Farm Management, JNKVV, Jabalpur. He is also serving as Principal Investigator, Madhya Pradesh Agriculture Market Intelligence Centre, Jabalpur. He has previously been associated as Co-Principal Investigator to project “An Evaluation of Krishi Upaj Mandies for Efficient Marketing of Agricultural Produce in Madhya Pradesh”. He has published several research papers in the field of Agricultural Economics in particular and Economics in general. He has co-authored Agriculture Atlas of the State of Madhya Pradesh (Part-I and II Dynamic).

Ms. Aradhana Singh Rajpoot is Senior Research Fellow in Madhya Pradesh Agriculture Market Intelligence Centre, Jabalpur. She has previously worked under project “An Evaluation of Krishi Upaj Mandies for Efficient Marketing of Agricultural Produce in Madhya Pradesh”.

title: 1  Introduction
text: The State of Madhya Pradesh is bestowed with 3,08,245 square kilometer of area with major river the Narmada and the Tapti flowing through it. It has 258 Agriculture Produce Market Committees (APMCs) which oversee the working of agricultural produce across eight division of the state. Out of these 258 APMCs 39, 41, 57 and 121 are respectively number of ‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’ and ‘D’ grade APMCs during 2019. The wide variation in number of notified commodities bought and sold in various yards across the states makes spatial distribution mapping a necessity. An atlas can provide valuable spatio-temporal understanding by way of graphical representation. The macro picture can reveal several patterns that are hard to visualize from large chunk of data. A series of map on same aspect over the years also facilitate comparison over a period of time. All this can greatly enhance the understanding of market and facilitate planning and policy making. Previously attempts were made at the national level to bring out Agriculture Market Atlas of India and various agricultural and horticultural atlas to depict spatial diversity across the state and India. However, there is no attempt at the state level to prepare Agriculture Market Atlas for the state of Madhya Pradesh. This first attempt in the State of Madhya Pradesh would greatly enhance the quality of policy making vis-a-vis help economist increase curiosity in agricultural economy of the Madhya Pradesh.

title: 2  Methodology
text:
This atlas was prepared using the data from official website of Madhya Pradesh Rajya Krishi Vipanan Board (MP Mandi Board), Bhopal. The R software for Statistical Computing (2022) was utilized along with sp (Pebesma and Bivand 2005) , rgdal (Bivand, Keitt, and Rowlingson 2022) and tmap (Tennekes 2018) packages. The book was prepared and compiled with the help of Quarto Markdown Publishing System(Allaire 2022). The shape file of Madhya Pradesh with district boundaries was obtained from NAHEP CAAST on “Skill Development to Use of Spatial Data for Natural Resources Management in Agriculture” located at College of Agriculture Engineering, JNKVV, Jabapur. For calculating the average price prevailing in the district and state, weights were assigned using arrivals. For categorization of markets, average values of price and arrivals for the state of Madhya Pradesh was considered. A district categorized as district with “High Price” if its annual average price was greater than the state average price for the given commodity else categorized as district with “Low Price”. Similarly, district having average arrivals above state average arrivals were categorized as districts with “High Arrivals” else categorized as district with “Low Arrivals”. For calculating during and before COVID price and arrivals, year 2020 and 2021 were considered as during COVID years.




Allaire, JJ. 2022. “Quarto: R Interface to ’Quarto’ Markdown Publishing System.” https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=quarto.


Bivand, Roger, Tim Keitt, and Barry Rowlingson. 2022. “Rgdal: Bindings for the ’Geospatial’ Data Abstraction Library.” https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=rgdal.


Pebesma, Edzer J., and Roger S. Bivand. 2005. “Classes and Methods for Spatial Data in r” 5. https://CRAN.R-project.org/doc/Rnews/.


R Core Team. 2022. “R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing.” https://www.R-project.org/.


Tennekes, Martijn. 2018. “Tmap: Thematic Maps in r” 84. https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v084.i06.

title: 3  Wheat
text:
Figure 3.1: Price and Arrivals of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2018




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total arrivals of Wheat during 2018 were 27676.842 000’ quintals. The highest arrivals of 2218.438 000’ quintals were reported in the district of Narmdapuram and the lowest reported arrivals of 5.475 000’ quintals were in the district of Anuppur. The average price of Wheat in the State of Madhya Pradesh was Rs. 1721.82 per quintals. The maximum price of Rs. 1905.09 per quintal was reported from the district of Vidisha and the minimum price of Rs. 1511.28 per quintal was reported from the district of Rewa.





Figure 3.2: Price and Arrivals of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2019




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total arrivals of Wheat during 2019 were 96758.418 000’ quintals. The highest arrivals of 5727.112 000’ quintals were reported in the district of Ratlam and the lowest reported arrivals of 27.177 000’ quintals were in the district of Anuppur. The average price of Wheat in the State of Madhya Pradesh was Rs. 1856.29 per quintals. The maximum price of Rs. 2000.23 per quintal was reported from the district of Vidisha and the minimum price of Rs. 1705.82 per quintal was reported from the district of Sheopur.





Figure 3.3: Price and Arrivals of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2020




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total arrivals of Wheat during 2020 were 76193.646 000’ quintals. The highest arrivals of 6361.131 000’ quintals were reported in the district of Ujjain and the lowest reported arrivals of 4.285 000’ quintals were in the district of Anuppur. The average price of Wheat in the State of Madhya Pradesh was Rs. 1805.62 per quintals. The maximum price of Rs. 1957.54 per quintal was reported from the district of Ashoknagar and the minimum price of Rs. 764.67 per quintal was reported from the district of Anuppur.





Figure 3.4: Price and Arrivals of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2021




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total arrivals of Wheat during 2021 were 60603.01 000’ quintals. The highest arrivals of 5761.298 000’ quintals were reported in the district of Ujjain and the lowest reported arrivals of 30.807 000’ quintals were in the district of Singrauli. The average price of Wheat in the State of Madhya Pradesh was Rs. 1869.05 per quintals. The maximum price of Rs. 2086.5 per quintal was reported from the district of Ashoknagar and the minimum price of Rs. 1618.59 per quintal was reported from the district of Shahdol.





Figure 3.5: Price and Arrivals of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh before COVID-19 outbreak




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total arrivals of Wheat before COVID-19 were 124435.26 000’ quintals. The highest arrivals of 6749.494 000’ quintals were reported in the district of Ratlam and the lowest reported arrivals of 32.652 000’ quintals were in the district of Anuppur. The average price of Wheat in the State of Madhya Pradesh was Rs. 1826.38 per quintals. The maximum price of Rs. 1978.7809488 per quintal was reported from the district of Vidisha and the minimum price of Rs. 1691.9122598 per quintal was reported from the district of Sheopur.





Figure 3.6: Price and Arrivals of wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh during COVID-19 outbreak




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total arrivals of Wheat during COVID-19 were 136796.656 000’ quintals. The highest arrivals of 12122.429 000’ quintals were reported in the district of Ujjain and the lowest reported arrivals of 42.06 000’ quintals were in the district of Singrauli. The average price of Wheat in the State of Madhya Pradesh was Rs. 1833.72 per quintals. The maximum price of Rs. 2008.3138823 per quintal was reported from the district of Ashoknagar and the minimum price of Rs. 1549.6777841 per quintal was reported from the district of Anuppur.





Figure 3.7: Production of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2018-19




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total production of wheat during 2018-19 was 24891217 tonnes. The highest production of 1254028 tonnes were reported in the district of Narmdapuram and the lowest reported production of 24249 tonnes were in the district of Anuppur.





Figure 3.8: Production of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2019-20




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total production of wheat during 2019-20 was 37507219 tonnes. The highest production of 1765718 tonnes were reported in the district of Ujjain and the lowest reported production of 33100 tonnes were in the district of Anuppur.





Figure 3.9: Production of Wheat across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2020-21




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total production of wheat during 2020-21 was 35666886 tonnes. The highest production of 2053482 tonnes were reported in the district of Dhar and the lowest reported production of 29325 tonnes were in the district of Anuppur.

title: 8  Lentil (Masoor)
text:
Figure 8.1: Price and Arrivals of lentil across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2018

The maximum price of Rs. 3787.08 per quintal was reported from the district of Seoni and the minimum price of Rs. 1275 per quintal was reported from the district of Khandwa.





Figure 8.2: Price and Arrivals of lentil across Districts of Madhya Pradesh for 2019




In the State of Madhya Pradesh, total arrivals of lentil during 2019 were 1603.765 000’ quintals. The highest arrivals of 250.78 000’ quintals were reported in the district of Sagar and the lowest reported arrivals of 0.026 000’ quintals were in the district of Morena. The average price of lentil in the State of Madhya Pradesh was Rs. 3802.72 per quintals.
